awd_titl_txt: Code: SciGirls! Media to Engage Girls in Computing Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Women continue to be underrepresented in computer science professions.  In 2015, while 57% of professional occupations in the U.S. were held by women, only 25% of computing occupations were held by women.  Furthermore, the share of computer science degrees going to women is smaller than any STEM field, even though technology careers are the most promising in terms of salaries and future growth.  Research suggests that issues contributing to this lack of computer science participation begin early and involve complex social and environmental factors, including girls' perception that they do not belong in computer science classes or careers.  Computer science instruction often alienates girls with irrelevant curriculum; non-collaborative pedagogies; a lack of opportunities to take risks or make mistakes; and a heavy reliance on lecture instead of hands-on, project-based learning.  Computer science experiences that employ research-based gender equitable best practices, particularly role modeling, can help diminish the gender gap in participation. In response to this challenge, Twin Cities PBS (TPT), the National Girls Collaborative (NGC) and Code.org will lead Code: SciGirls! Media for Engaging Girls in Computing Pathways, a three-year project designed to engage 8-13 year-old girls in coding through transmedia programming which inspires and prepares them for future computer science studies and career paths.  The project includes five new PBS SciGirls episodes featuring girls and female coding professionals using coding to solve real problems; a new interactive PBSKids.org game that allows children to develop coding skills; nationwide outreach programming, including professional development for informal educators and female coding professionals to facilitate activities for girls and families in diverse STEM learning environments; a research study that will advance understanding of how the transmedia components build girls' motivation to pursue additional coding experiences; and a third-party summative evaluation. 

Code: SciGirls! will foster greater awareness of and engagement in computer science studies and career paths for girls.  The PBS SciGirls episodes will feature girls and female computer science professionals using coding to solve real-world challenges. The project's transmedia component will leverage the television content into the online space in which much of 21st century learning takes place.  The new interactive PBSKids.org game will use a narrative framework to help children develop coding skills.  Drawing on narrative transportation theory and character identification theory, TPT will commission two exploratory knowledge-building studies to investigate: To what extent and how do the narrative formats of the Code: SciGirls! online media affect girls' interest, beliefs, and behavioral intent towards coding and code-related careers?  The studies aim to advance understanding of how media builds girls' motivation to pursue computer science experiences, a skill set critical to building tomorrow's workforce. The project team will also raise educators' awareness about the importance of gender equitable computer science instruction, and empower them with best practices to welcome, prepare and retain girls in coding.  The Code: SciGirls! Activity Guide will provide educators with a relevant resource for engaging aspiring computer scientists. The new media and guide will also reside on PBSLearningMedia.org, reaching 1.2 million teachers, and will be shared with thousands of educators across the SciGirls CONNECT and National Girls Collaborative networks. The new episodes are anticipated to reach 92% of U.S. TV households via PBS, and the game at PBSKids.org will introduce millions of children to coding. The summative evaluation will examine the reach and impact of the episodes, game and new activities. PIs will share research findings and project resources at national conferences and will submit to relevant publications.  This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GSE: Research on Gender in S&E

por.por_cntn:
Code: SciGirls! goal was to employ the powerful and proven combination of the PBS SciGirls television series, online activities and outreach to engage and broaden the participation of girls (ages 8-13) in computer science. The deliverables included: five new SciGirls episodes featuring different groups of girls coding with a woman technology mentor, aligned hands-on activities, a PBSKids coding game Code Quest, and training for 24 educators (from 12 educational organizations) to run SciGirls technology programs reaching 240 girls and 460 family members. Episodes and activities include:

501: High Tech Tide: Florida SciGirls make a splash, uniting with marine biologists to digitally track spotted eagle rays in the Gulf of Mexico. They share their data in a livestream presentation and explore the Mote Marine Laboratory. Activity: Signal Senders: Explore how scientists track animals using acoustic tags.

502: Game Changers: Teaming up with professional game designers, the SciGirls create a hands-on board game adventure and code an app, then share the fun at a professional game maker showcase. Activity: Awesome Game Race: Design your own game.

503: Super Sensors: Los Angeles SciGirls inspired by high-tech NASA sensor technology design and code wildlife cameras to capture images of the animals in their neighborhood. Activity: Keep Out!: Build an alarming doormat to keep people out of your room.

504: Cartoon Coders: Fueled by their passion for technology and social justice, the SciGirls create a computer animation that urges kids to take action in their own communities. Activity: Story Starters: Create a storyboard to plan out a story.

505: Code Concert: SciGirls collaborate with singers on a concert for Deaf and hearing audiences. They code software that paints with music - creating a stunning visual display of a live vocal performance. Activity: Code Creators: Learn about computer programming by writing pseudocode with friends to describe a simple activity.

Intellectual Merit: The fifth season of SciGirls premiered on PBS stations in December 2019. It received a 2020 Day Time Emmy Nomination for Best Educational Series and won a 2021 Gracie Award for Best Family-TV National show (a major film industry award for media by and for women and girls). The project included a summative evaluation on the outreach program's impact on girls interest, beliefs, and behavioral intent towards coding and code-related careers and a research study on the narrative transport and character identification within episodes and the game and their impact on girls viewers and game players. The independent evaluation findings from Knight-Williams demonstrated that despite many challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, nine of twelve organizations implemented their programs as TPT intended, and educators involvement in the project improved their confidence in teaching coding and computational thinking. Participating girls enjoyed outreach programs and were interested in most program elements and resources. With respect to coding outcomes, girls interests, beliefs, and behavioral intentions toward coding and code-related careers all increased significantly after participating in their program.

Directed by Knight Williams, the research produced two studies that explored the extent to which the narrative formats of the shows and the Code Quest game affected girls? interest, beliefs, and behavioral intent towards coding and code-related careers. Viewing three episodes produced significant and positive gains for 5th grade girls in four (of six) outcomes measured in the study: interest in coding activities, interest in coding applications, interest in code-related jobs or careers, and belief in their ability to code. Girls reported experiencing a high level of overall narrative involvement and show enjoyment while watching the shows, as well as high levels of involvement with each individual dimension comprising overall narrative involvement: story, character, and attentional focus. Playing the game produced significant and positive gains for 5th grade girls in one of the four coding outcomes measured in the study: girls? belief in their ability to code. Overall, girls experienced a high level of story involvement while playing Code Quest, with story involvement having a significant positive effect on girls? game enjoyment and on pre-post gains in their belief in their ability to code and behavioral intention to do coding in the future.

Broader Impacts: Episodes have aired on public television stations nationwide, PBSKids.org and the PBSKids Video App and on PBS LearningMedia and the SciGirls CONNECT educator site. Episodes also stream on Amazon and the SciGirls YouTube channel. The episodes garnered 25 million streams on PBS platforms and 1.3 million viewer impressions on air. Episodes aired on 446 channels in 47 states with 100% penetration into the top 25 markets and 93% of all U.S. households. This coverage is remarkable, particularly in comparison to subscription services (i.e. Netflix, Hulu, HBO) that only appear in some U.S. households. Activities are in both in English and Spanish and are available for educators at the SciGirlsCONNECT.org website serving 5,300 educators (http://www.scigirlsconnect.org/) and PBS LearningMedia reaching 1.8 million educators annually (https://www.pbslearningmedia.org/collection/scigirls/).

 


Last Modified: 03/23/2022
Modified by: Rita Karl

por.por_txt_cntn:
Code: SciGirls! goal was to employ the powerful and proven combination of the PBS SciGirls television series, online activities and outreach to engage and broaden the participation of girls (ages 8-13) in computer science. The deliverables included: five new SciGirls episodes featuring different groups of girls coding with a woman technology mentor, aligned hands-on activities, a PBSKids coding game Code Quest, and training for 24 educators (from 12 educational organizations) to run SciGirls technology programs reaching 240 girls and 460 family members. Episodes and activities include:

501: High Tech Tide: Florida SciGirls make a splash, uniting with marine biologists to digitally track spotted eagle rays in the Gulf of Mexico. They share their data in a livestream presentation and explore the Mote Marine Laboratory. Activity: Signal Senders: Explore how scientists track animals using acoustic tags.

502: Game Changers: Teaming up with professional game designers, the SciGirls create a hands-on board game adventure and code an app, then share the fun at a professional game maker showcase. Activity: Awesome Game Race: Design your own game.

503: Super Sensors: Los Angeles SciGirls inspired by high-tech NASA sensor technology design and code wildlife cameras to capture images of the animals in their neighborhood. Activity: Keep Out!: Build an alarming doormat to keep people out of your room.

504: Cartoon Coders: Fueled by their passion for technology and social justice, the SciGirls create a computer animation that urges kids to take action in their own communities. Activity: Story Starters: Create a storyboard to plan out a story.

505: Code Concert: SciGirls collaborate with singers on a concert for Deaf and hearing audiences. They code software that paints with music - creating a stunning visual display of a live vocal performance. Activity: Code Creators: Learn about computer programming by writing pseudocode with friends to describe a simple activity.

Intellectual Merit: The fifth season of SciGirls premiered on PBS stations in December 2019. It received a 2020 Day Time Emmy Nomination for Best Educational Series and won a 2021 Gracie Award for Best Family-TV National show (a major film industry award for media by and for women and girls). The independent evaluation findings from Knight-Williams demonstrated that despite many challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, nine of twelve organizations implemented their programs as TPT intended, and educators involvement in the project improved their confidence in teaching coding and computational thinking. With respect to coding outcomes, girls interests, beliefs, and behavioral intentions toward coding and code-related careers all increased significantly after participating in their program.

Directed by Knight Williams, the research produced two studies that explored the extent to which the narrative formats of the shows and the Code Quest game affected girls? interest, beliefs, and behavioral intent towards coding and code-related careers. Viewing three episodes produced significant and positive gains for 5th grade girls in four (of six) outcomes measured in the study: interest in coding activities, interest in coding applications, interest in code-related jobs or careers, and belief in their ability to code. Playing the game produced significant and positive gains for 5th grade girls in one of the four coding outcomes measured in the study: girls? belief in their ability to code. Overall, girls experienced a high level of story involvement while playing Code Quest, with story involvement having a significant positive effect on girls? game enjoyment and on pre-post gains in their belief in their ability to code and behavioral intention to do coding in the future.

Broader Impacts: Episodes have aired on public television stations nationwide, PBSKids.org and the PBSKids Video App and on PBS LearningMedia and the SciGirls CONNECT educator site. Episodes also stream on Amazon and the SciGirls YouTube channel. The episodes garnered 25 million streams on PBS platforms and 1.3 million viewer impressions on air. Episodes aired on 446 channels in 47 states with 100% penetration into the top 25 markets and 93% of all U.S. households. This coverage is remarkable, particularly in comparison to subscription services (i.e. Netflix, Hulu, HBO) that only appear in some U.S. households. Activities are in both in English and Spanish and are available for educators at the SciGirlsCONNECT.org website serving 5,300 educators (http://www.scigirlsconnect.org/) and PBS LearningMedia reaching 1.8 million educators annually (https://www.pbslearningmedia.org/collection/scigirls/).
